Linux: Yes: unstable from kernel 2.6.29 to 3.9; stable since 3.10

Windows 9x: Partial read-only with third party driver
Windows NT: Yes : Win7, Vista SP1, can be added to XP SP2, SP3
with Ext2Fsd (complete) or Ext2 IFS (partial, no large inodes) or Ext2Read (read-only, also on LVM2)
with Ext2Fsd (complete) or Ext2 IFS (partial, no large inodes) or Ext2Read (read-only, also on LVM2)
Partial with Ext2Fsd (partial, extents limited) or Ext2Read (read-only, also on LVM2)
Mac OS X: with ExtFS (full read/write),  fuse-ext2 (partial), and  ext4fuse (read-only)
FreeBSD: Partial support in kernel since version 10.1 (read-only) or with ext4fuse (read-only)

AIX: Partial on diskettes only, through dos* commands

DOS: Yes since DOS 3.0, FAT16B since DOS 3.31
AIX: Partial on diskettes only, through dos* commands
Partial on diskettes only, through dos* commands

Linux: Partial - write support occurs if journal is empty, but requires a force mount.

Windows NT: included until v3.51, third-party driver until 4.0

Linux: Yes Kernel 2.2 or newer, or with NTFS-3G or ntfsprogs
Mac OS X: with NTFS-3G or partial read-only in kernel

Linux: Partial read-only with tool or kernel module

Windows NT: Yes since Windows Server 2012 and Windows 8.1

Windows 9x: Partial read-only support of UDF 1.02 since Win95 OSR2

Linux: with 3rd Party kernel module or FUSE
